title: In New Orleans, culinary tradition gets a tongue-tingling shake-up
text:
Gulotta is one of a number of inventive chefs reinvigorating the local dining scene. The Mississippi delta city has long been known for its culinary bounty: not just the fusion flavours of creole and Cajun cuisines, but also the formal dining traditions of grand old-school restaurants such as Antoine’s and Galatoire’s.

In the 14 years of rebuilding that followed the devastation of Hurricane Katrina, a new generation of chefs has put its own spin on the city’s dining scene.

In New Orleans, seasonal eating isn’t just about produce; it’s also about seafood. — Brian Landry, Jack Rose

Among them is Brian Landry, who helms Jack Rose restaurant in the Pontchartrain Hotel, where the theatrical interiors feature velvet banquettes, chandeliers, hanging ferns and a disco ball. Although Jack Rose has a relaxed vibe, Landry says he drew inspiration from some of the city’s more traditional dining rooms.

Jack Rose's Caesar Salad is prepared at the table. Randy Schmidt

“Growing up and experiencing restaurants like Galatoire’s, it felt like anything could happen at any moment. We want to capture that feel, to build moments into the menu,” he says.

Nothing on Landry’s simple-sounding menu is quite what it seems. The Caesar salad is made with kale and shaved cauliflower; the chicken parmigiana is an extraordinarily juicy, extraordinarily crispy fried chicken. Cooked sous vide then crisped in corn starch batter, it is served on a bed of New Orleans’ spicy tomato sauce, with parmesan shaved over the top as you watch.

Brian Landry specialises in serving straightforward dishes that are anything but.

Landry’s menu also reflects his love of local seafood. “This is where the fresh water from the Mississippi and the salt water from the Gulf of Mexico meet,” he explains. “In New Orleans, seasonal eating isn’t just about produce; it’s also about seafood. The crawfish season is just coming to an end, blue crab is getting more and more plentiful, so is red snapper.”

Landry may be serving fresh takes on old classics but Greg Sonnier’s restaurant, Gabrielle, is itself a revived classic. The much-loved restaurant had been going for more than a decade when it was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. Although Sonnier always planned to reopen the restaurant, finding new premises proved to be challenging and it was 12 years before Gabrielle opened its doors in a new location in the Tremé neighbourhood.

Advertisement

Sonnier was always known for his Cajun cooking, and the dishes served up in the cheery yellow dining room hold true to that heritage. “It’s hard not to have a gumbo on the menu, or my barbecue shrimp pie, or the roast duck with orange-sherry sauce,” Sonnier says. However, he happily admits to tweaking regional classics.

Landry seeks to create an "anything could happen at any moment" vibe at Jack Rose. Christian Horan

“So many people ask, ‘Do you have jambalaya?’ that I decided to put it on the menu – but I do it my way. My family came from Nova Scotia and got kicked out of there, so I thought, how would a chef in Nova Scotia cook jambalaya? I took a shrimp and okra stew and added lobster and langoustines – that’s my take on a jambalaya.”

Sonnier says that while the city’s chefs may be changing the rules, they are sticking with at least one local tradition. What sets New Orleans apart from other cities, he says, is its abiding passion for food. “As a child we used to go visit relatives in Cajun country and what we would do is eat. All the aunts and uncles were in competition with each other, they all talked about each other’s food. Even while you were eating, you were talking about food. There are not many places in the country where people do that.”

Gabrielle is testament to the city's revitalisation post Hurricane Katrina.

description: Vietnamese gumbo here, langoustine jambalaya there, the city’s best chefs are mixing it up to grand effect.
